pros:
-Super supportive environment for graduate students to work while also studying full time; plenty of flexibility
-Absolutely wonderful and friendly people; my close colleagues feel like family
-Gorgeous campus and location
cons:
CGU has been undergoing some immense changes over the past few years. Being jostled from interim president to interim president has been chaotic and political. The biggest shift has been going to a centralized structure which has robbed many of the schools within the university of their culture and autonomy. This also has also created a lot of resentment from the staff within the schools who are being stripped of their rights (ex. departments were nearly barred from spending money and hosting commencement celebrations for their graduating students). 

Also, everyone is feeling the squeeze of budget cuts and it is hurting morale....from staff all the way down to students. 

However, I am hopeful that the new president, Len Jessup, will help to mitigate these issues with his new vision for the institution.

review_title: Graduate student worker - RA and TA
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Claremont, CA
pros: Hey, we're here any ways! Good way to make contacts and build relationships for research and future job opportunities.
cons: Depending on the job, the pay is poor. Many TA positions pay very little considering the amount of work that is required outside of the classroom and that in order to support oneself, being a TA isn't a drop in the bucket. RA positions may pay better but the limitation on hours that can be paid  worked during pay periods means that there have been times I am not paid for parts of the  projects I should be. That limitation also means it is difficult to ONLY be an RA as a means to get income.

pros: My various positions at CGU held certain characteristics in common. All of my roles, including research, tutoring, and teaching, provided a strong sense of independence. I was free to pursue my work in the way I saw best. I worked at my own pace, according to my own schedule, and focused on what I felt were the biggest priorities. The campus is calm and quiet, supportive to such a work environment.
cons: There was not a whole lot of interaction from my supervisors. Because of the independent nature of the campus, at times I was not 100% sure what was expected of me, or if I was meeting the expectations of my supervisors. The campus can also get quiet lonely at times.

review_title: a lot of work to do by everyone involved to improve genuine support of and appreciation for others
pros: educational atmosphere, students seeking learning, some faculty research into real-life problems; people agree that the campus is beautiful with many trees and lawns; many concerts, lectures, movies, art exhibits, sports events open to staff with little or no cost; many very dedicated people working to educate students and solve societal problems, as well as cooperate with staff to run the campuses
cons: traditionally low salaries, general disrespect of staff by administration; lack of parking spaces; insular colleges often have difficulty agreeing on joint policy; complaints of clubby atmosphere; lack of integrity in human resources offices in dealing with employees leading to high turnover in some departments

pros:
Teamwork - Everyone really likes to work together on tasks
Collaborative - There is respect for many different and diverse ideas
Understanding - People are understanding when things come up 
Flexible - Schedules are flexible and management does a good job in making sure employee is happy
cons:
Long Commute from Major City in LA 
Slow turn around on projects, many times there would just be extension after extension which made it seem like not a lot got completed

review_title: Fulfilling, engaged work as a graduate student researcher
pros: Amiable connections with professors (which is fantastic for really learning how life as a researcher/practitioner works), good way to build one's career while in school,
cons: Pay is limited by grant funding and academic budgets, so you might get decently lucky or you might be harshly underpaid considering the high cost of tuition and the fact that most of the researchers effectively have Master-level degrees in the relevant field

review_title: A very good university with untapped human capital
pros: This school attracts and admits many strong applicants ready to be challenged by great professors who have strong research credentials and high student performance expectations. The environment is academic and collegial.
cons: Some administrative departments have ongoing problems that have lasted too long and need to change. This can be frustrating for employees who want to improve both the student (client) experience and the efficient management of limited financial resources.

review_title: A rewarding experience for students who desire to work in higher education administration.
job_title: Student Services Assistant-(Federal Work Study) in Claremont, CA
pros: You get the opportunity to learn a lot about how higher education administration works. The experience gained here functions as great preparation for careers in higher education.
cons: Like many institutions, federal work study programs are the lay of the land, so students looking for upward mobility must seek full time opportunities elsewhere.

pros: The culture is open and appreciative of our work.  I often feel welcomed in all areas of the campus which are not often in other higher educational institutions. Most of the faculty are awesome to staff and students.
cons: The fact that the pay is so low many of left the institution for better wages, rather than the culture. I often wonder that a new hire is harder to start and pay, why train again!

pros: Good people and a fun environment. The infrastructure is very nice and the classes are interesting as well as the professors.
cons: Some times I felt as though there were some holes in the infrastructure of the administration and it is always so hot here.

pros: Flexible work hours.  Some staff/faculty are great to work with.
cons: Poor pay as a student worker--because of a poor endowment and bad fundraising.  Also there's administrative bloat.  Cut the staff (there is no need to have a big student affairs office at a grad only school) and put that money to better use elsewhere, either in funding the students or hiring new faculty.

pros: Let me know when you find some. (I'm just writing words because there are no pros but Glassdoor has a  20 word minimum)
cons: Highest turnover I've ever seen. I know one person quit on her first day, before lunch! Nepotism, promoting low qualified people to management, extremely low morale. Admissions standards are lowered often so they can just take people's money. Major financial problems. Can't say enough to warn people to GET OUT and stay away! You're better off working for United Airlines or going to school at Trump U!

review_title: A great place to work as a full-time student!
pros: As a student, management is very flexible on how and when my work get's done. They really want to see you advance in your career or academic field.
cons: Sometimes difficult to balance being both a student and an employee at the same time. There is often no separation of roles.

review_title: What it's like to work at Claremont Graduate University
pros: Great administration that is communicative and cares about student experiences. Higher management are encouraging and positive to work for.
cons: Sometimes it is hard to get things done when there are few people to a team due to the size of the university.

pros:
Very friendly faculty members
Very friendly campus and learning environment
Very experienced faculty members in terms of research and teaching.
Very prestigious school and students
cons: Too small and unless living in the area, not too many people know about the school and the quality of its education.

review_title: Great place to study, but limited work and internship opportunities.
pros: Small, intimate, respectful work and professional environment.
cons: Location is not great (Inland Empire), and the resources for optimizing systems and talent seem limited.

pros: The university has an excellent reputation and is beautiful.  It is located close to popular attractions (within an hour) and yet is far enough away for students to engage in focused study.  I'm working for these pros.
cons: Diversity is an issue.  A really big issue.

review_title: Great place to work, the staff believes in collaboration and cooperation.
pros: The support from management for student workers is great!
cons: Budget is always a constraint.

pros: There are a lot of great staff and faculty members here. The students are fun to work with. The location can't be beat.
cons: Things move slow here. Innovation is not supported like it should and hr/payroll can be difficult to navigate.

pros: I enjoy my job and the people that I work with here at CGU!  Faculty, staff and students always seem to be friendly and helpful.
cons: Traffic getting to and from work can be difficult sometimes.

pros: A small university that has some great people working for it. Mission and purpose sound. Interaction with interesting students.
cons: Constantly changes the admin structure. Salaries below market.
